text: The Ohio Act requires the State to maintain its budget in balance. But it is up to the Governor and the General Assembly to see how this is done and how the burden of balance should be shared. (Joff) John Kasesh took the lead in that process with what he called the "post budget," an expenditure scheme that includes reductions for local governments, school districts and government agencies to close the budget deficit of $800 billion. Casić disclosed his spending plan on March 15, 2011. In a public forum at the Center for Thoughts in Playhouse Square, Sean State, Nina Turner said she feared that the Governor would "balance the budget on the back of the staff" and weaken the Government's ability to deliver services. When "the governor announced his "work budget, 99 people from the tax department were left the next day," she said. Polyte Fact Ohio decided to check this out. On March 16, the state said that it would close seven regional centres for taxpayers on June 30 - the end of the fiscal year - resulting in the loss of approximately 100 jobs. The Commissioner of Taxes, Joe Tetsa, sent e-mail notifications to staff members at the regional centres for taxpayers ' services in Akron, Cincinnati, Cleveland, Dayton, Toledo, Yongstown and Zenesville.
